questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of left-sided pleuritic chest pain and breathlessness. On examination, he is distressed and tachypneic, with tracheal deviation to the right, a hyper-resonant percussion note on the left, and absent breath sounds on the left side. Chest X-ray reveals a <2 cm air space on the left side. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a stable patient with a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax (<2 cm), the first-line management is needle aspiration.

  • Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP): Occurs in young, otherwise healthy individuals due to rupture of subpleural blebs.
  • Management depends on size and stability:
    • <2 cm rim of air, stable: Needle aspiration (simple, less invasive).
    • >2 cm or unstable: Intercostal tube drainage.
    • Recurrent or persistent air leak: Consider pleurodesis (chemical pleural adhesion) or surgery.
  • High-flow oxygen can help absorb air faster but is not definitive treatment for symptomatic cases.
  • In this patient: Stable, small (<2 cm) pneumothorax → needle aspiration is appropriate.

Explanation of incorrect options

High-flow oxygen therapy (Option A): Helps accelerate reabsorption but insufficient as sole therapy in symptomatic pneumothorax.

Insertion of an intercostal tube (Option B): Reserved for larger (>2 cm), recurrent, or unstable pneumothorax.

Chemical pleural adhesion procedure (Option C): Used for recurrent pneumothorax, not in first episodes of small PSP.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who had two episodes of haemorrhagic shock due to intestinal haemorrhage and post-operative secondary haemorrhage was admitted to intensive care. During the following weeks, this was followed by bronchopneumonia with symptoms of sepsis persisting over several weeks. Chest x-ray showed progressive changes in the interstitial tissues, and he became more significantly hypoxic. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure was 13 mmHg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ARDS is characterized by acute hypoxemia, diffuse interstitial/alveolar infiltrates, and normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (<18 mmHg), typically following sepsis, trauma, or shock.

  • ARDS (Adult Respiratory Distress Syndrome):
    • Triggered by sepsis, trauma, shock, pneumonia, or transfusion.
    • Pathophysiology: Diffuse alveolar damage → ↑ alveolar-capillary permeability → non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema → hypoxemia refractory to oxygen.
    • CXR: Bilateral diffuse infiltrates (interstitial + alveolar).
    • PCWP: Normal/low (<18 mmHg), ruling out cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • This case:
    • Precipitating event: Hemorrhagic shock + sepsis.
    • Persistent hypoxia + diffuse interstitial changes + PCWP 13 → consistent with ARDS.

Explanation of incorrect options

Congestive cardiac failure (Option A): Causes pulmonary edema but with elevated PCWP (>18 mmHg).

Pneumocystis pneumonia (Option B): Occurs in immunocompromised, insidious onset, not post-shock with normal PCWP.

Pulmonary embolism (Option C): Causes acute dyspnea and hypoxia, but not diffuse bilateral infiltrates on CXR.

ARDS:

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient was involved in a car accident and sustained multiple fractures. He had been in the ICU not long before there was a suspicion of severe respiratory distress syndrome. Which of these would help to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A pulmonary capillary wedge pressure ≤18 mmHg confirms ARDS by excluding cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is defined by acute onset hypoxemia, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on imaging, and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • Differentiating ARDS from cardiogenic pulmonary edema is crucial.
  • The Berlin definition of ARDS emphasizes excluding hydrostatic (cardiac) pulmonary edema.
  • This is done by assessing pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP):
    • ARDS → PCWP ≤18 mmHg
    • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema → PCWP >18 mmHg
  • Other findings like diffuse infiltrates on imaging or ventilatory requirements indicate severity but are nonspecific.
  • Thus, measuring PCWP is the confirmatory test in suspected ARDS.

Explanation of incorrect options

CT scan of the chest (Option A): Shows bilateral ground-glass opacities/consolidation but cannot reliably distinguish ARDS from cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

Oesophageal manometry (Option B): Assesses esophageal motility disorders; unrelated to ARDS diagnosis.

Requirement for ventilatory support (Option D): Common in ARDS due to hypoxemia but is a consequence, not a diagnostic criterion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is admitted with a history of syncopal episodes and breathlessness. There is no prior history of recent travel. On examination, she looks distressed. Her pulse rate is 120 beats per minute, blood pressure 85/60, and JVP is elevated by 5 cm. Respiratory rate 26 per minute, there is a soft systolic murmur at the left sternal edge. Breath sounds are clear. Investigations show: HB 12.4 g/dL, Blood gases pH 7.42, PaCO2 24.7 mmHg, PaO2 63.75 mmHg. She was put on high-flow oxygen and given low molecular weight heparin. The next step in the management of this patient should be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has massive pulmonary embolism with shock, requiring urgent CTPA to confirm and immediate thrombolysis for definitive management.

  • Clinical features: Sudden syncope, hypotension (BP 85/60), tachycardia (HR 120), raised JVP, hypoxemia, and respiratory alkalosis → all strongly suggest massive pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • Blood gases: Hypoxemia (PaO2 63 mmHg), hypocapnia (PaCO2 24.7 mmHg), and near-normal pH = typical for acute PE.
  • Clear chest + systolic murmur: No pneumonia or LV failure; murmur likely from tricuspid regurgitation due to acute RV strain.
  • Immediate step: In a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected PE, CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) is the diagnostic test of choice.
    • If positive and patient is unstable → thrombolysis (e.g., Alteplase).
    • If CTPA is not possible → bedside echocardiography to look for RV strain.
  • Why not heparin alone? Heparin prevents further clot propagation but does not treat existing life-threatening embolus. In shock, thrombolysis is required.

Explanation of incorrect options

High dose aspirin (Option A): Used in acute coronary syndromes, not in pulmonary embolism.

Coronary angiography (Option B): For ACS/MI workup; clinical and ABG picture favors PE, not MI.

Intravenous unfractionated heparin (Option D): Helpful for anticoagulation, but in hemodynamically unstable PE, anticoagulation alone is insufficient-thrombolysis is indicated.

choices.text: Contact ITU to arrange for the patient to be ventilated
Insert a large-bore needle into the right hemithorax
Arrange for urgent portable chest XR
Check arterial blood gases and commence BIPAP

questions.text: A 35-year-old man whose condition has suddenly deteriorated is brought to the ER. He had arrived 30 minutes earlier with a 2-hour history of central pleuritic chest pain and breathlessness. He collapsed while awaiting CXR. He is cyanosed and has a pulse of 130/min and BP of 85/45 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is reading 81%, despite high-flow oxygen via a rebreather mask. Respiratory examination reveals reduced breath sounds in the right lung field with deviation of the trachea towards the left. What immediate course of action should be taken?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has a tension pneumothorax, a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate needle decompression before confirmatory investigations.

  • Clinical features: Sudden chest pain, dyspnea, cyanosis, hypotension (shock), tachycardia, unilateral absent breath sounds, and tracheal deviation → classical for tension pneumothorax.
  • Pathophysiology: Air trapped in pleural space under pressure compresses the lung and mediastinum, reducing venous return and cardiac output → rapid cardiovascular collapse.
  • Management principle: Do not wait for imaging or ABG - immediate needle decompression in the 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line (large-bore cannula), followed by chest tube insertion.
  • Why this choice? Only urgent decompression relieves intrathoracic pressure, improves venous return, and saves the patient's life.

Explanation of incorrect options

Contact ITU for ventilation (Option A): Delays lifesaving decompression; ventilation alone won't help in tension pneumothorax.

Arrange urgent portable chest XR (Option C): Imaging is contraindicated if tension pneumothorax is suspected clinically-treatment must be immediate.

Check ABG and start BIPAP (Option D): Delays management and non-invasive ventilation worsens pneumothorax.

Cardinal features of a Tension pneumothorax:

  • Enlarged hemithorax
  • Absent air entry
  • Deviation of the mediastinum to the contralateral side
  • Hyper resonance
  • Hypotension
  • Raised JVP

choices.text: Request a chest X-ray in expiration
Start low molecular weight heparin and request CT pulmonary angiography
Start low molecular weight heparin and request a V/Q scan

questions.text: A 60-year-old asthmatic lady is admitted with a sudden onset of left-sided pleuritic chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath. Arterial blood gases are as follows: pH of 7.30, pO2 of 56.2 mmHg, and pCO2 of 28.5 mmHg. Chest XR is normal. She is on oxygen. What is the most appropriate immediate action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In suspected acute pulmonary embolism (PE) with hypoxemia and normal chest X-ray, immediate anticoagulation and confirmation with CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the best next step.

  • Clinical suspicion: Sudden pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, hypoxemia, respiratory alkalosis (↓pCO2 from hyperventilation) + normal CXR strongly suggest pulmonary embolism.
  • ABG findings in PE: Typically shows hypoxemia + hypocapnia + respiratory alkalosis (though here pH is slightly acidotic due to severity).
  • Management principle:
    • If clinical suspicion is high → start anticoagulation immediately (LMWH or UFH) to prevent clot propagation.
    • Confirm diagnosis with CT pulmonary angiography (gold standard in stable patients).
  • Why not delay? Waiting for D-dimer or other tests wastes time-early LMWH improves survival.

Explanation of incorrect options

Request a chest X-ray in expiration (Option A): Useful for small pneumothorax, not in suspected PE.

Request D-dimer (Option B): D-dimer is nonspecific, often elevated in elderly/asthmatics; not appropriate when clinical suspicion is already high.

Start LMWH and request a V/Q scan (Option D): V/Q scan is an alternative but less specific, especially in patients with pre-existing lung disease like asthma. CTPA is preferred.

choices.text: Give an intravenous infusion of aminophylline
Repeat bronchodilator therapy and arrange repeat arterial gases
Arrange for non-invasive positive pressure ventilation

questions.text: A 75-year-old lady is admitted with an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). One hour after admission, she remains distressed with a respiratory rate of 35 per minute and is peripherally cyanosed. Repeated arterial blood gases show a severe respiratory acidosis with a pH of <7.2. Which of the following treatments is recommended?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Severe respiratory acidosis (pH <7.25) in acute COPD exacerbation despite optimal medical therapy is an indication for non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIV).

  • Pathophysiology: COPD exacerbations lead to worsening airflow obstruction, impaired gas exchange, hypoxemia, and CO2 retention.
  • ABG findings: This patient has severe type II respiratory failure with marked hypercapnia and acidemia (pH <7.2), showing ventilatory failure.
  • Medical therapy already given: Bronchodilators, steroids, antibiotics (if indicated), and controlled oxygen are the initial management.
  • Next escalation: When despite these, the patient remains tachypneic, cyanosed, and develops severe acidosis, ventilatory support is required.
  • Role of NIV: Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation reduces work of breathing, improves alveolar ventilation, corrects CO2 retention, improves pH, and reduces need for intubation.
  • Guideline recommendation (NICE/ERS/ATS): NIV is first-line ventilatory support in acute exacerbations of COPD with hypercapnic respiratory failure and pH <7.35, especially if <7.25. Intubation is considered if NIV fails.
  • Why not others: Aminophylline, steroids, or repeat nebulizers are supportive but do not address ventilatory failure in this context. NIV is life-saving here.

Explanation of incorrect options

Give an intravenous infusion of aminophylline (Option A): Aminophylline is rarely used now due to limited benefit and significant toxicity; not first-line in acute ventilatory failure.

Give intravenous hydrocortisone (Option B): Corticosteroids are useful in exacerbations to reduce inflammation, but they act slowly and do not correct acute hypercapnic acidosis.

Repeat bronchodilator therapy and arrange repeat arterial gases (Option C): The patient already received initial therapy; persisting severe acidosis indicates this is insufficient and escalation to ventilatory support is mandatory.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of depression is brought to the accident and emergency department after being found unconscious in a garage. A friend said that he complained of a headache, then had nausea and vomiting. He then became unarousable. Oxygen saturations are 95% on air, and breath sounds are clear on auscultation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Unconsciousness with headache, nausea, vomiting in a closed garage environment with normal SpO2 strongly suggests carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

  • Source of exposure: CO is produced by incomplete combustion of fuels (car exhaust, fires, poorly ventilated stoves/garages).
  • Mechanism: CO has 200-250 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin → reduced oxygen delivery to tissues → cellular hypoxia.
  • Clinical features: Early-headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting; Later-confusion, collapse, seizures, coma, cardiac arrhythmias, and death.
  • Why SpO2 is misleading: Standard pulse oximeters cannot differentiate between oxyhemoglobin and carboxyhemoglobin → falsely normal/near-normal oxygen saturations despite tissue hypoxia.
  • Diagnosis: Suspected clinically in the right context (enclosed space, faulty combustion source) and confirmed by measuring carboxyhemoglobin levels in blood.
  • Management: Immediate 100% oxygen (non-rebreather mask) to displace CO from hemoglobin; hyperbaric oxygen therapy in severe cases.
  • Context of depression: Raises suspicion of intentional CO exposure (suicide attempt).

Explanation of incorrect options

Pulmonary eosinophilia (Option A): Presents with cough, wheeze, fever, eosinophilia on labs; not with acute unconsciousness in a garage.

Pulmonary embolism (Option B): Causes sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, tachycardia; not headache or collapse in a closed environment.

Pneumocystis pneumonia (Option C): Seen in immunocompromised (e.g., HIV) with fever, progressive dyspnea, dry cough, hypoxemia; not acute neurological collapse.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with breathlessness, cough and fever. On examination, she has basal crackles in the lung fields. Circulating precipitins to Micropolyspora faeni are positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of serum precipitins to Micropolyspora faeni confirms the diagnosis of Farmers' lung, a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by moldy hay exposure.

  • Cause: Farmers' lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis (extrinsic allergic alveolitis) due to inhalation of thermophilic actinomycetes (Micropolyspora faeni, Thermoactinomyces vulgaris) from moldy hay or straw.
  • Pathophysiology: It is an immune-mediated condition (Type III and Type IV hypersensitivity reactions) leading to alveolitis and interstitial inflammation.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Acute: Breathlessness, cough, fever, malaise, basal crackles occurring hours after exposure.
    • Chronic: Progressive exertional dyspnea, weight loss, fibrosis.
  • Investigations:
    • Positive serum precipitins (IgG antibodies) against offending antigen (e.g., Micropolyspora faeni).
    • HRCT: Ground-glass opacities, centrilobular nodules, mosaic attenuation.
    • PFTs: Restrictive pattern with ↓DLCO.
  • Management: Avoid exposure (mainstay), corticosteroids in severe cases, supportive care.
  • Key diagnostic clue in the question: Micropolyspora faeni precipitins → specific for Farmers' lung.

Explanation of incorrect options

Pigeon fanciers' lung (Option A): Another form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but due to avian proteins in bird droppings/feathers, not Micropolyspora faeni.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (Option B): Occurs in asthmatics/CF patients; caused by Aspergillus fumigatus with bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and ↑IgE; not related to moldy hay exposure.

PCP infection (Option D): Caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompromised patients, presents with fever, dry cough, hypoxemia; no link with precipitins or moldy hay.

questions.text: A 40-year-old worker presents with wheezing and breathlessness, which seem to improve over weekends and holiday periods when he is not working. What is he most likely to be exposed to at work?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Occupational asthma caused by platinum salts exposure is characterized by work-related wheezing and improvement on holidays.

  • Occupational asthma definition: A reversible airway obstruction due to sensitization to workplace allergens.
  • Platinum salts: Common occupational cause, especially in chemical and metal refining industries; exposure leads to IgE-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • Clinical features: Wheezing, breathlessness, cough that improve during periods away from exposure (holidays/weekends).
  • Mechanism: Platinum salts act as haptens, binding to proteins and triggering immune-mediated bronchospasm.
  • Diagnosis: Based on history of symptom pattern (work-related), spirometry, peak flow variability at and away from the workplace, and specific IgE tests.
  • Management: Avoidance of exposure (key), inhaled corticosteroids/bronchodilators if needed, workplace safety measures.

Explanation of incorrect options

Avian bloom (Option B): Refers to exposure to bird proteins → causes hypersensitivity pneumonitis (pigeon fancier's lung), not occupational asthma.

Aspergillus clavatus (Option C): Causes malt worker's lung (hypersensitivity pneumonitis), presenting with fever, dyspnea, and cough after exposure to moldy barley, not asthma.

Work in the Silver industry (Option D): Causes argyria (skin pigmentation due to silver deposition), not respiratory wheezing or asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following is found in subjects acclimatised to high altitudes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At high altitude, hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction leads to raised pulmonary artery pressure as part of acclimatization.

  • High-altitude physiology: At altitude, low barometric pressure reduces alveolar and arterial oxygen levels → hypoxemia.
  • Immediate response: Hyperventilation occurs, improving oxygenation but leading to respiratory alkalosis.
  • Pulmonary response: Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction diverts blood to better-ventilated alveoli but globally increases pulmonary vascular resistance → elevated pulmonary artery pressure.
  • Chronic adaptation: With acclimatization, erythropoietin increases RBC mass and hemoglobin concentration, enhancing oxygen delivery.
  • Cardiac output: Initially rises due to sympathetic stimulation but normalizes after acclimatization.
  • Other features: People may experience acute mountain sickness, polycythemia, and in some cases chronic mountain sickness.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Increased MCHC (Option A): Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration remains normal; at high altitude there is increased RBC count and hemoglobin, not MCHC.

Periodic respiration (Option C): Seen transiently during initial stay at high altitude (Cheyne-Stokes breathing), but not a feature of acclimatization.

Reduced cardiac output (Option D): Cardiac output is initially increased, then returns to near normal levels; it is not reduced in acclimatized individuals.

questions.text: An 18-year-old was brought to the emergency department by her friends as she had turned blue. She was well otherwise. On examination, she has central cyanosis; all other parameters are normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrate-contaminated water causes methemoglobinemia, which presents with central cyanosis despite normal cardiopulmonary status.

  • Methemoglobinemia cause: Nitrates (commonly from contaminated well water or fertilizers) oxidize ferrous iron (Fe2+) in hemoglobin to ferric form (Fe3+), forming methemoglobin.
  • Pathophysiology: Methemoglobin cannot bind oxygen effectively, reducing oxygen delivery to tissues.
  • Clinical features: Central cyanosis (blue lips, tongue, mucosa) with otherwise normal pulse, blood pressure, and lung examination. Often, SpO2 by pulse oximetry is falsely low (~85%) and does not improve with oxygen.
  • Diagnostic clue: Cyanosis with normal cardiopulmonary exam in a young person points to a dyshemoglobinemia rather than respiratory/cardiac disease.
  • Treatment: Methylene blue (electron donor) reduces methemoglobin back to hemoglobin; supportive oxygen therapy as well.
  • Relevance: Known as "blue baby syndrome" in infants, but can occur in older individuals after significant nitrate exposure.

Explanation of incorrect options

Carbon Monoxide Poisoning (Option A): Causes headache, dizziness, collapse, cherry-red skin; not cyanosis, and SpO2 appears normal.

Lead Poisoning (Option B): Causes anemia, neuropathy, abdominal pain, gum lead lines; does not cause acute cyanosis.

Anorexia Nervosa (Option D): Leads to weight loss, amenorrhea, electrolyte disturbances; cyanosis is not a presenting feature.

questions.text: A 63-year-old diabetic presents with pyrexia, productive cough, and shortness of breath for 5 days. She has RLL consolidation and a small unilateral pleural effusion on CXR. Which is a marker of poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diabetes mellitus is a poor prognostic marker in pneumonia due to impaired immunity, delayed resolution, and increased risk of complications.

  • Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP): Prognosis is influenced by host factors, severity of infection, and comorbidities.
  • Diabetes mellitus: Patients have impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, phagocytosis, and cell-mediated immunity, predisposing to severe infections and poor recovery.
  • Prognostic impact: Diabetes increases risk of complications (empyema, abscess, bacteremia), prolonged hospitalization, and mortality in pneumonia.
  • Other risk factors: Advanced age, chronic lung disease, renal failure, and immunosuppression also worsen prognosis, but in this stem diabetes is the standout poor prognostic marker.
  • Severity scoring (CURB-65): Confusion, Urea >7 mmol/L, Respiratory rate ≥30, Blood pressure <90/60, Age ≥65. Diabetes is not part of CURB-65 but is recognized as an independent poor prognostic factor.

Explanation of incorrect options

Temp >38°C (Option A): Fever indicates infection but is not in itself a poor prognostic marker; hypothermia (<36°C) is actually worse.

WBC >15,000/µL (Option B): Leukocytosis shows infection severity but by itself does not predict poor outcome as reliably as comorbidities.

Age (Option C): Age >65 is a poor prognostic factor, but in this case, diabetes is more directly linked with worse outcomes.

questions.text: A 61-year-old, heavy smoker, with a BMI of 37 kg/m2, presents with impotence, nocturia and depression. He is hypoxic at rest on air and has ankle oedema. Which is the most appropriate investigation to determine the aetiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient likely has obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with obesity hypoventilation syndrome, and a sleep study (polysomnography) is the gold standard diagnostic test.

  • Clinical clues:
    • Obesity (BMI 37 kg/m2) → strong risk factor for OSA.
    • Impotence, nocturia, depression → classic sequelae of OSA due to intermittent hypoxia and sleep fragmentation.
    • Hypoxia at rest, ankle oedema → suggests pulmonary hypertension/right heart strain secondary to chronic nocturnal hypoxemia.
  • Pathophysiology of OSA: Recurrent upper airway collapse during sleep → intermittent hypoxia → sympathetic activation, pulmonary hypertension, systemic hypertension, depression, metabolic dysfunction, erectile dysfunction.
  • Polysomnography (sleep study):
    • Monitors airflow, chest wall movement, oxygen saturation, ECG, EEG.
    • Provides apnea-hypopnea index (AHI), confirming OSA and its severity.
  • Why other tests are not first-line here: They may show consequences (like hypoxemia, cor pulmonale), but do not establish the aetiology.
  • Management after diagnosis: Weight loss, CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure), avoidance of alcohol/sedatives, management of comorbidities.

Explanation of incorrect options

Arterial blood gas (Option A): Will show hypoxemia ± hypercapnia but only indicates respiratory failure, not the cause.

Chest X-ray (Option B): May show cardiomegaly or features of pulmonary hypertension but will not confirm OSA.

Ventilation-perfusion scan (Option C): Used for pulmonary embolism diagnosis, not for obesity-related sleep-disordered breathing.

choices.text: Results are consistent with Bronchopulmonary dysplasia.
Blood gases suggest type 1 respiratory failure.
Results are consistent with late severe asthma

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of deteriorating breathlessness and dyspnoea. Blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.25, a pCO2 of 52 mm Hg, a pO2 of 63.75 mm Hg, and a base excess of -4. Which of the following interpretations is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ABG shows respiratory acidosis with hypoxemia, characteristic of late severe (life-threatening) asthma where CO2 retention occurs.

  • In acute asthma, the early stage usually shows hypoxemia with low pCO2 (due to tachypnea and hyperventilation).
  • However, when the disease progresses to life-threatening severe asthma, the patient tires and ventilation becomes inadequate, leading to CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis.
  • ABG Findings:
    • pH 7.25 → acidemia.
    • pCO2 52 mmHg → hypercapnia (normal 35-45 mmHg).
    • pO2 63.75 mmHg → hypoxemia (normal >80 mmHg).
    • Base excess -4 → mild metabolic acidosis, probably due to tissue hypoxia.
  • This pattern (respiratory acidosis + hypoxemia in a young asthmatic) confirms late severe asthma.

Explanation of incorrect options

Results are consistent with Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (Option A): BPD is a chronic neonatal lung condition seen in preterm infants requiring ventilation, not in a previously healthy 16-year-old.

Blood gases suggest type 1 respiratory failure (Option B): Type 1 respiratory failure = hypoxemia with low or normal CO2. Here, CO2 is elevated, consistent with type 2 respiratory failure.

Immediate intubation is required (Option C): While severe asthma with rising CO2 is dangerous, intubation is not immediate unless there is impending respiratory arrest, exhaustion, or altered consciousness. This ABG indicates severity, but the answer tested here is the underlying diagnosis: late severe asthma.

choices.text: No movement of the left hemidiaphragm
No movement of the right hemidiaphragm
Paradoxical movement of the left hemidiaphragm
Paradoxical movement of the right hemidiaphragm

questions.text: A 65-year-old man came to the hospital for worsening breathlessness. He was a chronic smoker and had previously been diagnosed with lung cancer. Chest X-ray revealed elevation of the left hemidiaphragm, and left phrenic nerve palsy was suspected. Which of the following findings on fluoroscopy of the diaphragm will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phrenic nerve palsy causes paradoxical upward movement of the affected hemidiaphragm during inspiration.

  • The phrenic nerve (C3-C5) supplies motor innervation to the diaphragm.
  • When functioning normally, both hemidiaphragms move downward during inspiration due to contraction.
  • In phrenic nerve palsy, the affected hemidiaphragm is paralyzed and instead of descending, it moves paradoxically upward during inspiration, because the negative intrathoracic pressure generated by the normal side pulls it upwards.
  • This paradoxical motion is best demonstrated on fluoroscopy of the diaphragm ("sniff test").
  • Thus, paradoxical upward movement of the left hemidiaphragm confirms left phrenic nerve palsy in this patient.

Explanation of incorrect options

No movement of the left hemidiaphragm (Option A): Paralysis rarely produces complete immobility; paradoxical movement is more diagnostic.

No movement of the right hemidiaphragm (Option B): The problem is on the left side, not the right.

Paradoxical movement of the right hemidiaphragm (Option D): Wrong side; the right hemidiaphragm is unaffected.

Causes of phrenic nerve palsy are :

  • Pneumonia
  • Pleurisy
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Substernal goitre
  • Neoplasms
  • Thoracic surgery
  • Herpes zoster infection
  • Vasculitis
  • Diabetes

choices.text: pH 7.16; paCO2 70 mm; paO2 50 mm; HCO3 24 mmol/L
pH 7.24; paCO2 80 mm; paO2 55 mm; HCO3 30 mmol/L
pH 7.32; paCO2 60 mm; paO2 70 mm; HCO3 30 mmol/L
pH 7.41; paCO2 40 mm; paO2 50 mm; HCO3 24 mmol/L

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of progressive shortness of breath. Her family brought her in because she was increasingly sleepy during the last 24 hours. She was diagnosed with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease 3 years ago and has a FEV1 less than 50% of predicted. She has an oxygen concentrator at home. Examination revealed depressed consciousness and a respiratory rate of 24 with shallow breaths. There were decreased breath sounds with minimal air movement. If an arterial blood gas on room air were to be performed, which of the following results would you expect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ABG shows severe type 2 respiratory failure with respiratory acidosis and metabolic compensation, typical of an acute-on-chronic COPD exacerbation with CO2 retention.

  • Type 2 respiratory failure (hypercapnic): Defined as pCO2 >50 mmHg. Here, pCO2 = 80 mmHg, indicating severe CO2 retention.
  • pH 7.24: Shows acidotic blood due to CO2 accumulation (respiratory acidosis).
  • Compensatory mechanism: Chronic COPD leads to renal retention of HCO3, here 30 mmol/L, partially buffering the pH.
  • Hypoxemia: pO2 = 55 mmHg, showing type 2 respiratory failure with concurrent hypoxemia.
  • Clinical correlation: Shallow breathing, depressed consciousness, and minimal air entry are consistent with severe CO2 retention and impending ventilatory failure.
  • Management: Requires urgent oxygen titration, non-invasive ventilation (NIV) to correct hypercapnia, and treatment of COPD exacerbation.

choices.text: Agitation should be managed with a benzodiazepine
A high inspired Oxygen concentration should be used routinely
Inhaled salmeterol is indicated as first-line therapy

questions.text: A 24-year-old asthmatic female is admitted with acute severe asthma. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In acute severe asthma, hypoxemia is common, and high-concentration oxygen should be administered to maintain oxygen saturation ≥94%.

  • Acute severe asthma: Characterized by severe airflow obstruction, hypoxemia, and risk of respiratory failure.
  • Oxygen therapy:
    • Essential to correct hypoxemia.
    • High inspired oxygen concentration is used routinely, titrated to maintain SpO2 ≥94%.
  • Other aspects of management:
    • First-line therapy: inhaled short-acting β2-agonists (SABA) like salbutamol, not salmeterol.
    • Systemic corticosteroids are indicated.
    • Monitoring ABG is important; rising CO2 indicates impending respiratory failure.
  • Clinical rationale: Oxygen is safe and lifesaving; unlike CO2, hypoxemia is immediately harmful to vital organs.

Explanation of incorrect options

Agitation should be managed with a benzodiazepine (Option A): Benzodiazepines are generally avoided in severe asthma as they can depress respiration.

Inhaled salmeterol is indicated as first-line therapy (Option C): Salmeterol is a long-acting β2-agonist (LABA) and not suitable for acute attacks; SABAs like salbutamol are preferred.

Normal arterial pCO2 is reassuring (Option D): In acute severe asthma, a normal pCO2 may indicate fatigue and impending ventilatory failure; hypoventilation can precede CO2 retention, so it is not reassuring.

questions.text: A 65-year-old obese man presents with night-time sweats, nocturia, poor concentration and daytime somnolence. To which of the following conditions does this diagnosis predispose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in obese individuals increases the risk of cardiovascular complications, including sudden death due to nocturnal hypoxia and arrhythmias.

  • Clinical clues:
    • Obesity, daytime sleepiness, poor concentration, nocturia, and night sweats point toward OSA/obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Recurrent upper airway collapse during sleep → intermittent hypoxia, sympathetic activation, hypertension, cardiac remodeling.
    • Chronic hypoxia increases risk of arrhythmias, pulmonary hypertension, and sudden cardiac death.
  • Complications:
    • Cardiovascular: Hypertension, arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, sudden death.
    • Metabolic: Insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes.
    • Neurocognitive: Poor concentration, daytime somnolence, depression.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed by sleep study (polysomnography).
  • Management: Weight reduction, CPAP therapy, avoidance of sedatives, management of comorbidities.

Explanation of incorrect options

Hypoglycaemia (Option A): OSA does not cause low blood sugar; it may actually be associated with insulin resistance, not hypoglycemia.

Hypotension (Option B): OSA typically causes hypertension, not hypotension.

Insulin sensitivity (Option C): OSA reduces insulin sensitivity, leading to insulin resistance, not increased sensitivity.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female is admitted with a depression of her consciousness level. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed:
pH 7.26
pO2 90 mmHg
pC02 29.25 mmHg
Standard bicarbonate 14.7 mmol/L
Which one of the following would account for these results?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has a primary metabolic acidosis with low bicarbonate, acidemia, and compensatory hyperventilation (low pCO2).

  • ABG analysis:
    • pH 7.26 → acidemia.
    • HCO3- 14.7 mmol/L → low, indicating a metabolic
    • pCO2 29.25 mmHg → lower than normal (normal 35-45 mmHg), consistent with respiratory compensation via hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing).
    • pO2 90 mmHg → normal, indicating adequate oxygenation.
  • Interpretation:
    • The primary problem is metabolic acidosis.
    • The lungs are compensated by blowing off CO2 to partially correct the pH.
  • Causes of metabolic acidosis:
    • Increased acid production: ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis.
    • Loss of bicarbonate: diarrhea, renal tubular acidosis.
  • Compensation: The respiratory system lowers CO2 according to Winter's formula:
    • Expected pCO2 ≈ (1.5 × HCO3-) + 8 ± 2 → here: (1.5×14.7)+8 ≈ 30 mmHg, matching the measured 29.25 mmHg → appropriate compensation.

Explanation of incorrect options

Analytical error (Option A): ABG values are internally consistent; compensation matches metabolic acidosis → unlikely.

Persistent vomiting (Option C): Causes metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis, due to loss of gastric HCl.

Respiratory acidosis (Option D): Would present with elevated pCO2, not reduced pCO2.

questions.text: You are asked to see a patient who attends the ER with shortness of breath. The chest X-ray shows right lower lobe consolidation. Which of the following features should prompt admission to the hospital?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A respiratory rate ≥30/min is a marker of severe pneumonia and indicates the need for hospital admission.

  • Severity assessment in pneumonia: Tools like CURB-65 and British Thoracic Society criteria consider respiratory rate, oxygenation, confusion, blood pressure, and age for admission decisions.
  • Respiratory rate:
    • RR >30/min is a major marker of severe pneumonia.
    • Reflects significant respiratory compromise and risk of deterioration.
  • Other parameters:
    • Oxygenation is important, but pO2 73.5 mmHg or SaO2 95% is not immediately alarming in isolation.
    • Audible bronchial breathing indicates consolidation but does not alone dictate admission.
  • Rationale: Early hospital admission for patients with severe clinical signs allows close monitoring, IV antibiotics, and supportive care.

Explanation of incorrect options

Audible Bronchial breathing (Option A): Sign of consolidation; important for diagnosis but not an indication for admission on its own.

pO2 of 73.5 mmHg (Option B): Mild hypoxemia; usually managed with supplemental oxygen and monitoring, not admission per se.

SaO2 of 95% (Option C): Normal oxygen saturation; does not indicate severe disease.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 32-year-old man was the driver of a car involved in a high-speed RTA 3 days ago. He has sustained a closed fracture of his femur, which has been treated surgically with an intramedullary nail, as well as fractures of his right clavicle and left radius. He was managed according to ATLS protocol when he attended the emergency department. On examination, he is acutely short of breath and has a temperature of 37.5 °C. The patient seems confused when you speak to him, and as you examine him, you note petechial haemorrhages. What do you think is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient exhibits the classic triad of fat embolism syndrome (respiratory distress, neurological changes, and petechial rash) following long bone fractures.

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Long bone fractures (femur, tibia) release fat globules from bone marrow into the bloodstream.
    • Fat emboli lodge in pulmonary capillaries → hypoxia and respiratory distress.
    • Systemic inflammatory responses may affect the brain → confusion, neurological symptoms.
    • Petechial rash occurs due to emboli in dermal capillaries.
  • Classic triad:
    • Respiratory distress (hypoxemia, tachypnea)
    • Neurological changes (confusion, agitation)
    • Petechial rash (usually on chest, conjunctiva, axillae)
  • Timing: Typically occurs 24-72 hours after trauma, consistent with this patient.
  • Investigations:
    • ABG: Hypoxemia
    • Chest X-ray: Bilateral infiltrates ("snowstorm" appearance)
    • Diagnosis is clinical, supported by history and examination.
  • Management:
    • Supportive care: Oxygen, ventilation if needed
    • Hemodynamic support
    • Early fracture stabilization reduces risk

Explanation of incorrect options

Asthma attack (Option A): No history of asthma; sudden respiratory distress post-trauma does not fit.

Chest infection (Option B): Mild fever may be present, but confusion and petechial rash are not typical; timing (3 days post-trauma) also favors fat embolism.

Pulmonary embolism (Option D): Typically presents with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, but petechial rash and neurological changes are absent.

questions.text: In the diagnosis of asthma, reversibility is defined as an increase in FEV1 by > __% after administration of albuterol.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asthma is confirmed by significant bronchodilator reversibility, defined as ≥12% increase in FEV1 from baseline after inhaled short-acting β2-agonist.

  • Spirometry in asthma: Measures airflow limitation and its reversibility.
  • Reversibility criteria:
    • Increase in FEV1 ≥12% and ≥200 mL from baseline after 15–20 minutes of inhaled short-acting β2-agonist (e.g., albuterol).
    • Reflects bronchial smooth muscle responsiveness, a hallmark of asthma.
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Differentiates asthma from COPD, which usually shows less reversibility.
    • Also useful in monitoring response to therapy.

questions.text: Central bronchiectasis is seen with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Central bronchiectasis is a hallmark feature of Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA), typically affecting the proximal bronchi.

  • Pathophysiology of ABPA:
    • Hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus fumigatus colonizing the bronchi.
    • Causes inflammation, mucus plugging, and fibrosis predominantly in central/proximal bronchi.
  • Imaging:
    • CT shows central bronchiectasis with normal peripheral bronchi.
    • Often associated with mucoid impaction ("finger-in-glove" appearance).
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Common in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis.
    • Early diagnosis prevents progression to diffuse bronchiectasis and pulmonary fibrosis.

Explanation of incorrect options

Cystic Adenomatoid Malformation (Option A): Congenital cystic lung lesion; does not typically cause central bronchiectasis.

Recurrent Aspiration (Option B): Usually causes basal or peripheral bronchiectasis, not central.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option C): Can obstruct bronchi causing localized bronchiectasis, but not the central pattern typical of ABPA.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

questions.text: Aspirin-sensitive asthma is associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) typically presents with asthma, nasal polyps, and hypersensitivity to NSAIDs.

  • Pathophysiology of aspirin-sensitive asthma:
    • Also known as Samter's triad or AERD.
    • Characterized by asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin/NSAIDs.
    • Ingestion of aspirin or other COX-1 inhibitors triggers bronchospasm due to leukotriene overproduction.
  • Clinical features:
    • Asthma exacerbations after NSAID ingestion
    • Nasal congestion and nasal polyps
    • Chronic sinusitis
  • Management:
    • Avoid aspirin/NSAIDs
    • Leukotriene receptor antagonists (e.g., montelukast)
    • Corticosteroids for asthma control

Explanation of incorrect options

Extrinsic asthma (Option A): Refers to allergic asthma, unrelated to aspirin sensitivity.

Urticaria (Option B): May occur with NSAID hypersensitivity but is not a defining feature of aspirin-sensitive asthma.

Obesity (Option D): Obesity can worsen asthma but is not associated with aspirin sensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings/symptoms is inconsistent with a diagnosis of asthma with impending respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tachycardia is a common feature in acute asthma but is not specific for impending respiratory failure, unlike obtundation, severe tachypnea, or paradoxical respiration.

  • Impending respiratory failure in asthma is indicated by:
    • Altered mental status: obtundation, confusion, drowsiness
    • Severe tachypnea: respiratory rate >30/min
    • Paradoxical respiration: chest wall moves inward during inspiration due to diaphragmatic fatigue
    • Silent chest or minimal air entry may also be present
  • Tachycardia is a general sign of stress or hypoxemia and is frequently seen in acute exacerbations of asthma but does not specifically indicate impending ventilatory failure.

Explanation of incorrect options

Obtundation (Option B): Indicates hypercapnia and hypoxia, a hallmark of impending respiratory failure.

Respiratory rate > 30/min (Option C): Sign of severe airflow limitation and respiratory distress, predictive of deterioration.

Paradoxical respiration (Option D): Suggests respiratory muscle fatigue and impending respiratory failure, requiring urgent intervention.
